From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
Some candidates have developed the.................for cheating in examinations
explanation: Having the "knack for" something means having aspecial skill or talentfor something. Knack fits best because other options cannot be paired with the preposition "for".

After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
The senator's house is the last word in comfort. This means that the senator

options.B: speaks about the comfort of his house
options.C: owns the last house on comfort street
options.D: has a house that is not comfortable

explanation: The phrase"the last word in"is an idiomatic expression that meansthe ultimate or best example of something.In this context,"the last word in comfort"means the highest level of comfort possible. Therefore, the sentence suggests that the senator's house is extremely comfortable.

From the words lettered A to D, below each of the following sentences, choose the word or group of words that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase as it is used in the sentence.
The students made scathing remarks about the vice-chancellor.
explanation: "Scathing" describes something harshly critical or severely damaging. In this context, it means that the students' remarks about the vice-chancellor were very critical and damaging in nature.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
The Principal has already summoned all the..........on the matter
explanation: This phrasing indicates that the Principal has called together the leaders of various departments involved in the matter. The use of the plural "heads" corresponds with "departments," implying that there are multiple leaders overseeing different departments. This construction is grammatically correct and aligns with standard usage when referring to the leaders of several departments.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
But for the timely intervention of the police, the kidnapper........by the angry mob.
explanation: "Would have been lynched" is the correct conditional structure for expressing a hypothetical situation in the past. It indicates that the lynching did not actually occur, thanks to the timely intervention of the police. Options A, C, and D either do not fit the grammatical structure for expressing a past hypothetical situation or do not convey the intended meaning appropriately. Therefore, option B, "would have been lynched," is the most suitable choice.

...........she was tired when we arrived, Mummy prepared a delicious dinner for us.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
You had better.......the examination
explanation:
We use "had better"to refer to the present or the future, to talk about actions we think people should do or which are desirable in a specific situation. The verb form is alwayshad, nothave. We normally shorten it to ’d betterin informal situations. It is followed by the infinitive
...had better (infinitive form)....
e.g. I had better go to the mall before it gets dark.
You had better leave him alone.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences:
Yesterday, I..........on the beach for half an hour.
explanation:
The confusion here is due to the irregular verb “to lie” (meaning to recline) and its past forms. So:
“I lie down now” (present)
“I lay down yesterday” (past)
“I have lain there before” (past participle)
